section.title: Unit: Living and non-living things
section.para: Key concepts:

list.item: movement - the action of moving
respiration - breathing (exchanging gases)
sensitivity - to be affected by something
nutrition - receiving or supplying food
excretion - to get rid of waste substances from the body
reproduction - to produce offspring (babies)
growth - to increase in size

section.title: Characteristics of living things
section.para: Although living things look different, they all have seven things in common. We call these things the seven life processes.
Let's take a look at each of these â€¦...

list.item: Humans and animals use their bodies to move from one place to another.
Plants turn towards the light.
Humans and animals use the oxygen in the air to breathe.
When plants exchange gases we call this transpiration.

para.emphasis: All living things responds to change (sensitivity)

list.item:
Humans, animals and plants respond to changes in the environment. They notice changes in their surroundings and react accordingly.
When you are feeling cold, you will put on a jersey.
When it becomes winter some animals hibernate.
In autumn some trees' leaves change colour.
Food gives all living things the energy they need.
Green plants produce their own food through a process called photosynthesis.
Humans and animals eat these plants to get energy.

para.emphasis: All living things has to get rid of waste substances (excretion)

list.item: Humans and animals have to get rid of waste substances from their bodies. They do this through sweating and by going to the toilet.
Plants get rid of waste water through the process of transpiration.
Humans and animals have babies.
New plants grow from seeds.
Human and animal babies grow into adults.
Seedlings grow into plants.

section.para: All seven of the life processes must happen for something to be living.
I would like to introduce you to Mrs Nerg. She is going to help you remember the seven life processes.
M - Movement
R - Respiration
S - Sensitivity
N - Nutrition Use the first letter of each word to spell Mrs Nerg
E - Excretion
R - Reproduction
G - Growth

section.title: Activity - Understanding the seven life processes

para.emphasis: The reason for doing this activity:

section.para: To see whether you understand the seven life processes.
1. Pictures of various objects (provided in the table)
1. Look at the table below.
2. Evaluate each picture in the first column.
3. In columns 2 to 8, for each life process, tick whether it applies to that object.

para.emphasis: Do I understand the seven life processes?

section.title: Characteristics[c] of non-living things
section.para: Non-living things are different from living things because they do not do all of the seven life processes.
Think about a car. Answer "YES" or "NO".

entry.para: Y - engine uses air to sustain combustion
Is it sensitive to changes in the environment?
Does it need energy (food) to be able to move?
Does it get rid of waste substances?

section.para: So, if we were to give a car a mark out of 7 for the life processes, what would you give it? 4 out of 7
Is a car a living or non-living thing?
Why do you say so?

entry.para: It does not do all seven the life processes.

section.title: Activity - Distinguishing between living and non-living things

para.emphasis: The reason for doing this activity:

section.para: To see whether you can distinguish between living and non-living things.
1. Various objects that you and your friends can collect and bring to school.
2. Chalk board / White board
1. On the board your teacher will write the following headings:

list.item: Living
Was living
Can live again
Was never living

section.para: 2. Take turns to show the objects you brought.
3. Decide under which heading your object belongs.
4. Write it under the correct heading on the board.
5. Complete the table with the results.

para.emphasis: These answers will depend on the objects brought by the pupils.
Can I distinguish between living and non-living things?

section.title: Activity:(Alternative to the previous activity - or both?)

para.emphasis: The reason for doing this activity:

section.para: To see whether you can distinguish between living and non-living things.
1. Look at the pictures above.
2. Decide in which category each picture belongs.
3. Complete the table with the results.

para.emphasis: Can I distinguish between living and non-living things?

section.title: Questions
section.para: Read the following story and then answer the questions that follow.
The Spirit in the Tree
(A Zulu fable)
(www.gateway-africa.com/stories/The_Spirit_in_the_Tree_Zulu.html)

There was once a girl whose mother had died and whose stepmother was very cruel to her. One day, when she was crying at her mother's grave, she saw that the earth of the grave parted and a stalk came out, which grew into a sapling and soon into a tree. The wind rustled its leaves and the tree whispered to the girl, telling her that her mother was near and that she should eat the fruits of the tree. The girl did and the fruits were very tasty and made her feel much better.

This happened every day from then on, but as soon as the cruel step-mother discovered what was happening, she went to her husband, the girl's father, and insisted that he had the tree cut down. The tree lay withering and the girls wept on its maimed trunk for a long time, until she heard a whisper and saw a lump growing up from the trunk. It grew and grew until it was a pumpkin. There was a hole in it from which leaked a trickle of juice. The girl licked up a few drops and found them very nourishing, but again her step-mother soon found out and one dark night cut the pumpkin off and threw it on the dung heap.

The next day the girl wept and wept until she heard a trickling sound and saw a little stream, which whispered, "Drink me, drink me." She did and felt much refreshed, but now the step-mother made the girl's father throw sand in the stream and bury it.

The girl went back to the grave where she cried and cried. She had been sitting there a long time when a man appeared from the bush. He saw the dead tree and decided it was just what he needed to make a bow and arrows, for he was a hunter.

He talked to the girl who told him that the tree had once grown on her mother's grave. He liked her and decided to go to her father and ask for her hand in marriage. The father consented on condition that the hunter killed a dozen buffalo for the wedding feast.

The hunter had never killed more than one buffalo at a time - that was difficult enough! But this time, taking his bow and arrows, he had not been in the bush long when he saw a herd of a dozen buffalo resting in the shade.

Setting one of his new arrows to his bow, he let fly. The first buffalo sank down dead. And the second, and the third. An hour later the sweating hunter came back to tell the father to send men to bring the meat to the village.
There was a big feast when the hunter married the poor girl who had lost her mother.
1. Name 5 non-living things mentioned in the story. (5)
2. Name all the things from the story that uses oxygen. (7)
What life process does this refer to? (1)
3. Give an example from the story of: (5)

list.item: movement:Chopping down the tree / hunting buffalo with bow and arrow / covering the stream with sand / hunter walking out of the bush _______________________________________________________________
nutrition:girl eating fruit / girl licking juice / girl drinking water_______________________________________________________________
growth:sapling growing into a tree / lump growing into a pumpkin_______________________________________________________________

section.para: 4. The tree in which the spirit lived most probably grew from a seed. What do we call this life process? (1)

section.title: Unit: Features of plants
section.para: Key concepts:

list.item: Function - the job it does
Chlorophyll - a substance in leaves giving a plant its green colour
Photosynthesis - the process by which a plant produces its own food
Fertilisation - when male and female parts of the plant come together to make a seed
Germinate - begin to grow and develop

section.title: Basic structures of flowering plants
section.para: All plants have different parts, each with its own function. Most plants have roots, stems, leaves and flowers. Many plants grow from seeds.
Let's take a look at each part of the plant and each function that it has.
This is the part of the plant that is normally found underground. The roots have two very important functions:

list.item: The roots anchor the plant in the ground.
The roots absorb water and nutrients from the soil.

section.para: This part of the plant connects the roots to the rest of the plant. The stem also has two functions:

list.item: The stem supports the leaves, flowers and fruit.
The stem carries water and minerals to the other parts of the plant.

section.para: A growing plant stem.
A tomato plant stem. http://www.flickr.com/photos/22206162@N03/3686817791/
This part of the plant is normally green. Chlorophyll gives the leaves its green colour. Some leaves change colour during autumn.
Leaves have an extremely important function.

list.item: The leaves catch the sunlight and uses it to make food for the plant. This process is known as photosynthesis.

section.para: This food gives the plant its energy. When animals and humans eat plants we get energy from the plant.
This is the pretty, colourful part of the plant. The flowers play a very important role in making new plants.

list.item: The flowers make fruit and seeds.
The flowers also make pollen that is necessary for fertilisation.
The colours of the flowers attract bees and other insects. These insects carry pollen from one flower to another.

section.para: This part of the plant is found inside fruit.

list.item: Seeds make new plants.

section.para: Dandelion seed. http://www.flickr.com/photos/the_yes_man/4648999621/
Coral tree seeds. http://www.flickr.com/photos/tgerus/4662650273/

section.title: Activity - Identifying the different parts of a flowering plant

para.emphasis: The reason for doing this activity:

section.para: To see whether you can identify the different parts of a plant.
1. Drawing of a flowering plant.
1. Look at the drawing below.
2. Label it scientifically.
3. Use the following labels:

list.item: root
stem
leaf
flower
seed

section.para: (Insert basic drawing of flowering plant that shows all 5 required parts)
The labeling must be done scientifically. The teacher must go through this / teach this at this stage:

list.item: the drawing must have a heading (printed in pen)
labeling lines must be in pencil
labeling lines must be drawn using a ruler
labeling lines must be parallel to the top / bottom of the page
labeling lines must touch the part of the drawing being labeled
labeling lines must end the same distance from the drawing (i.e. the labels must be in a vertical line underneath each other)
labels must be printed in pen

section.para: The correct labels must be used in the correct place

para.emphasis: Can I identify the different parts of a flowering plant?

section.title: What seeds need to germinate
section.para: Remember, we said that seeds make new plants? For a plant to grow from a seed, the seed needs to germinate. This means that it has to develop into a new plant by growing all the necessary parts.
Seeds need water and warmth to germinate.

section.title: Investigation - How a seed germinates

para.emphasis: What I want to find out:

section.para: In your own words write a short paragraph of what you want to find out by doing this investigation.
In your own words write a prediction of what you think will happen.
1. A bean
2. A saucer
3. Cotton wool
4. Tub / yoghurt container
1. Wrap your bean in cotton wool.
2. Place it in the saucer.
3. Wet the cotton wool.
4. Place the saucer with the cotton wool and bean in a sunny spot.
5. On a daily basis, ensure that the cotton wool remains wet.
6. Regularly check the progress of your bean's germination.
7. Plant your bean plant in a tub or yoghurt's container.
8. Record your findings below.
Which part of a plant was the first you saw sprouting from your bean?
(All blocks for drawing must be at least 10cm)
Make a scientific drawing of your bean and the first root.

labeling lines must be parallel to the top / bottom of the page
labeling lines must touch the part of the drawing being labeled
labeling lines must end the same distance from the drawing (i.e. the labels must be in a vertical line underneath each other)
labels must be printed in pen

entry.para: The correct labels must be used in the correct place

section.para: In your own words explain the order in which a seed germinates.

section.title: What plants need to grow
section.para: So now we have germinated a seed. This new little plant needs to be kept alive. To do this we need to make sure it has a few very important things.
Humans need a few things to live - we need healthy food, we need water, and we need air.
Plants are a little different.
(A picture with each heading)

They need food and water, but they also need sunlight to live. Plants use sunlight as a way to make food to grow through the process of photosynthesis. This food gives the plant its energy. When animals and humans eat plants we get energy from the plant.

Plants and animals, including humans, breathe in air. But plants use a different part of the air than we do. When we breathe, we use a part of the air called oxygen. We use the oxygen that we breathe in the air to feed the blood in our bodies.

Plants use a different part of the air, a gas called carbon dioxide. We breathe in oxygen and breathe out carbon dioxide. Plants do just the opposite - plants breathe in carbon dioxide and breathe out oxygen.

Plants also need water. Some plants need more water than others. The amount of water needed by a plant depends on the type of soil the plant is planted in, the climate of the area where the plant lives as well as the type of plant.

The roots of the plant absorbs water from the soil. This water allows nutrients from the soil to be transported through the stem to the leaves, flowers, fruits and seeds. Besides sunlight, plants also use water to make food for us through photosynthesis.
Most plants grow in soil.
Providing plants with rich soil will help it receive the nutrients and minerals it needs. The three most vital nutrients that a plant can receive are nitrogen, phosphorous and potassium.

Nitrogen helps the part of the plant that grows above the ground. Phosphorous helps the plant to produce flowers and seeds, and to develop a strong root system. Potassium acts like medicine for the plant and helps it to fight off disease. It also gives it strong stems.
To make sure plants get enough of these minerals we often add some fertiliser to help enrich the soil.
When all of these vital elements are available in the right quantities, a specific plant will grow naturally in that area.

Because there are many different kinds of plants, they grow in many different places. The place that a plant lives in is called a habitat. There are many different types of habitats that make a home for plants.

Some plants grow in the hot, dry desert. The desert is a habitat. These plants do not need as much water as other types of plants. Some plants grow in forests or caves that get very little sunlight. This is a special home just made for these types of plants.

section.title: Investigation - How the amount of water influences the growth of a plant
(As an alternative, the same experiment can be done with varying quantities of sunlight)

para.emphasis: What I want to find out

section.para: In your own words write a short paragraph of what you want to find out by doing this investigation.
In your own words write a prediction of what you think will happen.
1. Three of the bean plants germinated for the previous activity.
2. Three containers of exactly the same size.
3. Soil
1. Fill the three containers with exactly the same amount of soil.
2. Plant the three seedlings in the three containers.
3. Place the three containers next to each other in a spot that gets enough sunlight during the day.
4. Label the three containers as follows:

list.item: 1 - No water
2 - Little water
3 - Plenty of water

section.para: 5. Water the plants according to the labels.
6. Measure the three plants on the same day of the week every week.
7. Record your findings in the table below by writing the lengths of the plants in the blocks .
What happened? (Answer dependent on classroom environment)
Use the space provided below to draw a bar graph of your findings.

para.emphasis: (Insert axes with labels for the bar graph)

section.para: (Answer dependent on classroom environment)
In your own words explain the differences between the two plants. Why do you think this happened?

section.title: Visible differences between plants
section.para: There are many different types of plants. Plants differ in their size, the colour of their leaves, whether they have flowers or not, whether they loose their leaves or not, whether we can eat them, and many other distinguishable characteristics.
Take a look at the diagram below.
Let's take a look at a few examples: (A picture with each heading)

list.item: Usually have a single leaf
Examples are lawn grass, wheat, rice, barley and corn
Include roses, pansies, tulips and many other flowers found in our gardens.
Weeds are flowering plants that include dandelions, nettles and blackjacks.
Fruit trees provide many kinds of fruit
Examples are apples, lemons, bananas and peaches.
Vegetables are edible flowering plants.
Examples are carrots, potatoes, spinach, tomatoes and peas.
Herbs have scented leaves that are edible.
Examples are lavender, basil, sage and oregano.
Evergreen trees don't loose their leaves.
Deciduous trees lose all their leaves once a year - usually in autumn.
Bushes and shrubs are woody plants that are smaller than trees.
Bushes usually have one main stem.
Shrubs have more than one main branch growing from the ground.
Coniferous trees are evergreen.
Coniferous trees have "seeds" in cones, e.g. pine trees.
Grow in all parts of the world.
Some are as large as trees.
"Seeds" are called spores.
Grows close together in clumps on logs and walls in moist, shady areas.
"Seeds" are called spores.

section.title: Activity - What the leaves of different plants look like

para.emphasis: The reason for doing this activity:

section.para: To see the difference in leaves from various plants.
1. A number of leaves, each from a different plant. (Your teacher will tell you how many you need to collect.)
2. The names of the plants you collected the leaves from.
3. White paper.
4. Crayons.
1. Take one leaf and put it on a flat hard surface.
2. Make sure the veins are facing up, i.e. the leaf must be upside-down.
3. Place the white paper over the leaf.
4. Use the crayon on its side to gently colour on the paper over the leaf.
5. Label the leaf with the name of the plant it came from.
6. Repeat this process with all the leaves.
7. Give your page a suitable heading.
8. Complete the table below by filling in the name of each plant in the first column and then ticking the remaining columns that are applicable to that specific plant.
What happened? (Learner dependent answer)

para.emphasis: Does plants have differently shaped leaves?

section.title: Unit:Features of animals
section.para: Key concepts:

list.item: Vertebrate - animals that have a backbone (spine)
Invertebrate - animals that do not have a backbone (spine)
Characteristics - a quality that forms part of a persons character
Warm-blooded - the blood in the body remains at a constant temperature
Cold-blooded - the blood in the body has the same temperature as the surrounding temperature

section.title: Basic body plans of animals
section.para: When animals are classified the first thing we look at is whether the animal has a backbone (spine) or not.
If the animal has a backbone it is classified as a vertebrate. An example would be a dog. (Picture of dog)
If the animal does not have a backbone it is classified as an invertebrate, for example a jellyfish. (Picture of jellyfish)
In grade 4 we focus mainly on vertebrates. Let's take a look!
Vertebrates are divided into 5 main categories:

list.item: Mammals
Birds
Fish
Reptiles
Amphibians

section.para: In the next section we will look at these in more detail to see how they differ.

section.title: Visible differences between animals
section.para: The animals in the 5 different vertebrate groups have characteristics that distinguish them from each other.
These characteristics represent certain features the animals have and makes it possible for us to compare them and to notice the visible differences.
The following questions allow us to determine these characteristics:

list.item: What are their bodies covered with?
How are their babies born?
Are they warm-blooded or cold-blooded?
How do they breathe?
Where do they live?

section.para: Remember, one characteristic that all the animals in these five groups have in common, is the fact that they all have backbones.
Mammals are animals with a backbone. They have warm blood and hair or fur on their bodies. They give birth to living babies. Mammals are fed milk from mammary glands. Most mammals live on land.
(Insert drawing of mammal body plan similar to the one for birds. Does not have to be quite so detailed)

Birds are animals with a backbone. Birds are warm-blooded animals and lay eggs. They have a body covered with feathers and have wings to fly, although not all birds can fly. Some birds have flippers and can swim. Birds live on land.

Fish are animals with a backbone and their bodies are covered in scales. They are cold-blooded and live in water. They breathe through gills, which are slits on the sides of their bodies. They lay eggs in the water. Some fish are freshwater fish and other fish can only live in the sea.
(Insert drawing of fish body plan similar to the one for birds. Does not have to be quite so detailed)
Reptiles are animals with a backbone and are cold-blooded. They have a dry, scaly skin and lay eggs. Reptiles live on land.
(Insert drawing of reptile body plan similar to the one for birds. Does not have to be quite so detailed)

Amphibians are animals with a backbone and they lay eggs in the water. They are cold-blooded and have smooth, slippery skin. Amphibians live in water when they are young and on land when they are older.
(Insert drawing of amphibian body plan similar to the one for birds. Does not have to be quite so detailed)

section.title: Activity - Understanding the differences between vertebrates

para.emphasis: The reason for doing this activity:

section.para: To see whether you understand the characteristics of the 5 groups of vertebrates.
1. The table provided on the next page.
2. The information on the previous three pages.
1. Look at the pictures at the top of each column.
2. Look at the criteria in the first column.
3. In each block write a short phrase describing each of the criteria for each of the animals depicted.

entry.para: in water when young, on land when older

para.emphasis: Do I understand the different characteristics of the 5 groups of vertebrates?

section.title: Questions
section.para: 1. Look at the collage of animals below.
Make a heading for each of the 5 groups of vertebrates. (5)
Underneath each heading:

list.item: List the animals in the collage above that belongs to that group. (12)

Write a short paragraph about each group using the following questions:
What are their bodies covered with?
How are their babies born?
Are they warm-blooded or cold-blooded?
How do they breathe?
Where do they live?

section.para: Mammals - elephant, giraffe, mouse
covered in hair/fur, live babies, warm-blooded, lungs, on land
Birds - goshawk, sparrow, pigeon
covered in feathers, lays eggs, warm-blooded, lungs, on land
Fish - fish
covered in scales, lays eggs, cold-blooded, gills, in water
Reptiles - crocodile, ant-eater, lizard
covered in scales, lays eggs, cold-blooded, lungs, on land
Amphibians - bull-frog, tree-frog
wet, slippery skin, lays eggs, cold-blooded, first gills then lungs, first in water then on land

section.title: Unit: What animals need to survive
section.para: Key concepts:

list.item: Herbivore - animal that only eats plants
Carnivore - animal that only eats meat
Omnivore - animal that eats meat and plants
Camouflage - a way of hiding by looking the same as the surroundings
Predator - an animal that hunts or preys upon others
Prey - an animal that is hunted or killed by another for food
Indigenous - originating in a particular country

section.para: Animals need a number of things to survive. These things include food, water, shelter and even the ability to camouflage themselves.
Food (Picture for each heading/key concept used)
All animals need food to survive.
Some animals eat parts of plants, such as nuts, berries, twigs and leaves. These animals are called herbivores. Examples of herbivores are buck, elephants and tortoises.
Other animals eat insects, mice and other small rodents, and even larger animals. These animals are called carnivores. Examples of carnivores are lions, sharks and crocodiles.
Animals that eat parts of plants as well as other animals, are called omnivores. People are omnivores, so are bears and baboons.
Animals get water from puddles, streams and ponds.
Animals, and humans, need water to stay hydrated and to remain healthy. Water delivers oxygen and nutrients to different parts of the body and helps the body to function properly.
Shelter provides the animal and its babies with protection from the weather and its enemies, such as humans and other animals.
When all of these vital elements are available in the right quantities, a specific animal will live naturally in that area.
In other words, habitat is the physical area where the animal lives. An animal's natural habitat has everything it needs to live.
Animals use camouflage for two reasons.
Firstly, they use it to hide from predators. In other words, their camouflage helps them to hide from other animals that eat them.
Secondly, they use it to hide from their prey. In other words, when they are hunting it helps them to sneak up on other animals without being seen.
Animals are camouflaged in different ways.

Some animals hide against a background that has the same colour as they do. Others have stripes or spots that help break up their outline so that they don't stick out against the background. Some animals look like other objects and are, therefore, not very visible.
(Pictures of the three types of camouflage described above)

section.title: Activity - Understanding what animals need to survive

para.emphasis: The reason for doing this activity:

section.para: To see whether you understand what animals need to survive.
1. The information on the previous two pages.
2. Coloured pens or pencils.
3. A ruler.
1. Read through the section "What animals need to survive."
2. In the blank space provided, make a mind-map of the information. (Your teacher will show you what a mind-map looks like and how it works.)
(Include basic mind-mapping in teacher's guide)
3. Use a different colour pen or pencil for each sub-section.
4. Use a ruler to draw the lines connecting the main idea to the sub-sections.

para.emphasis: (This space should be a whole page)
Learner dependent - make sure all important information is present
Do I understand what animals need to survive?

section.title: Unit: Animal shelters
section.para: Key concepts:

list.item: Man-made
Natural

section.title: Man-made and natural shelters
section.para: Animals live in a variety of different kinds of homes from holes in the ground, to caves, nests and trees. Some animals use natural habitat for their homes. Other animals build their own home. Some animals even live in other animal's homes.
Look at the following picture of a few places where animals live.
Let's take a look at a few shelters that animals build and the materials they use.

Nests are built by birds and other animals in trees, on the ground and even in buildings. This is used as a home for them and especially for their eggs. Nests are usually bowl-shaped and made of twigs, leaves and grass held together by mud or saliva.
(Picture of a nest)

Bees live in very large colonies. They collect nectar and pollen from flowers which is used by the queen bee to make wax in her abdomen. The queen bee uses this wax to build a hive in the ground, in trees or even in buildings. The hive is made up of many six-sided cells stuck together. She lays her eggs in these cells.
(Picture of a bee-hive showing the 6-sided cells)

Small rodents such as squirrels, rabbits and moles, dig burrows in the ground or under logs and rocks to provide them with shelter. These burrows often form a network of tunnels under ground in which these animals live.
Ants and earthworms also live in the ground.
(Picture of an animal burrowing)
Spiders spin webs from silk produced by a gland in their abdomen called the spinneret. The web isn't only a home for the spider, it also helps the spider to catch it's prey.
(Picture of a spider web)
People often keep animals as pets. In such cases they do not find natural shelters to live in, but we provide them with man-made structures.
Look at the following examples:
http://farm5.staticflickr.com/4006/4449854125_3bd74d012b.jpg
Questions
1. Name four types of natural animal shelters.
2. Explain the difference between man-made and natural shelters.
3. Use the table below to compare the shelters of rabbits, pigeons and tuna fish.

entry.para: Where will I find the shelter?
What is the shelter made of?
Does the animal have to make the shelter?
Does the animal use a naturally occurring shelter?

section.para: 4. Why do rabbits, pigeons and tuna fish have different habitats and shelters?
5. Do you think it is fair to keep a pet rabbit in a cage where it cannot burrow? Give a reason for your answer.

section.title: Unit: Designing an animal shelter (T)
section.para: Remember earlier you dealt with living and non-living things. All living things need some shelter to protect them from harsh weathers.Structures are build by joining different parts together. Different materials are used to construct structures. They come in different sizes and shapes. Structures have different functions that they perform. Some protect, contain, supports or span a gap.
(Pictures of examples of structures performing different purposes)
Key Concepts:

list.item: Habitat vs shelter
Types of structures, i.e. Shell, mass or solid and Frame Structures

entry.para: find relevant information regarding the problem by using the inter-net, library asking other people
an open structure that give shape and support
to become stronger or to make stronger
colourless, odourless gas that is important to life processes and combustion
the manner in which the parts of something fit or function together eg. alarm system
are bars that turn around a fixed point
to work out the form and structure by making plans or sketches
to create or construct your model
judging the value or quality of your model

section.para: Shell structures mainly contain and/or protect the contents. A bird's egg protects the embryo growing inside it. A car gives some protection to its passengers . A pot contains the food inside it. The glass of a light bulb contains the filament and protects it from oxygen.

Mass or solid structures contains or supports by virtue of their mass. The mass of a solid dam wall holds back the water pressing against it. A brick has no framework but the slid mass of particles supports the load carried.

The primary function of a frame structure is support. The skeleton supports the body and provides anchoring points for muscles. The bones also acts as a system of levers. a frame structure must be able to carry the designed load in the right positions without it collapsing or falling over.

Frames are made of structural members joined to make a framework using triangulation to achieve strength with economy of material. Suitable members are selected for the anticipated forces - pulling, pushing or twisting.

list.item: List three types of structures.
Differentiate between shell and frame structures.
Give two functions of shell and frame structures.

section.para: a. Functions of Shell Structures
b. Functions of Frame Structures

list.item: From the table below, classify structures as shell or frame and make a tick in the appropriate column.

section.para: (A table indicating different structures, three columns, first for examples of structures, second indicating shell structures and last one frame structures)

list.item: Choose two examples from each of the types of structures and illustrate with drawings for each of the structures.

section.para: In Technology, the focus will be designing and constructing habitats for living things we learnt about earlier. Remember that before we design and make any product, we need to investigate existing products or invent new ones.

For the purpose of our assessment for this term, our focus will be on investigating and designing. In designing, a scenario setting a problem will be provided by your teacher.The scenario will also guide you in specifications to adhere to and constraints to guard against.Therefore, a brief will be expected of you on how you intend solving the problem.
Often in life, we need to solve problems. This sometimes requires of us to make an object that will be an acceptable solution to the specific problem.
When we need to make something, we need to follow a specific process. Let's take a look....

section.title: Setting the scenario[h]
section.para: Firstly we need to identify the problem. Then we need to come up with possible solutions.

In a town or city, birds often struggle to find food because they are not living in their natural habitat. We need birds in our environments to get rid of pests such as insects and bugs, and to assist in the fertilisation of some plants.
We need to find a way to attract birds to our neighbourhoods.
How do you think we can achieve this? Make a list of possible solutions.

(The teacher should lead the discussion to arrive at the solution of making a bird feeder. Instructions for making this should be included in the teachers guide. I will include this at the end of this document.)

section.title: 1. Brief[i]
section.para: In this step we write out our solution, i.e. we state what needs to be done.

section.title: 2. Specifications
section.para: During this step we list the features that the product must have. It is important that all the features are listed as this will ensure that your product is a successful solution to your problem.

section.title: 3. Constraints
section.para: Constraints are those things that limit or confine us in making our product.
We need to think about the following:

list.item: How big can (or must) my product be?
Which materials do I have available to make this product?
How much will it cost?
Which tools do I have available that I can use?
How much time do I have to finish my product?

section.para: Constraints in making my _________________________:

section.title: 4. Planning to make the product
section.para: The next step in the process is planning. Here we break the product up into the different parts it will consist of. We also decide what each part will be made of and how this will be done.
A table works well for this step.

entry.para: What material will I use for this part?
How will I make this part?

section.title: 5. Drawing/designing the product
section.para: In this step you make a drawing of what you want your product to look like. Your drawing must be labeled according to the MES-principle:

list.item: M - Materials used for the specific part of your product
E - Explanation of how the specific part works
S - Size of the specific part

section.para: (A whole page should be available for this step)

section.title: 6. Making the product
section.para: Before starting the process of making your product, remember to get together all the materials and tools you will use.
Keep your design brief, specifications, constraints and drawing close by and always keep these in mind. Your product MUST confirm to the specifications and constraints you have identified.

section.title: 7. Evaluating the product
section.para: After you have made your product, you need to evaluate it. This means you must decide whether your product will be able to solve the problem you identified at the beginning.
To do this you can ask the following questions:

list.item: Will my product solve the problem?
Did I stick to the specifications? (Ask this question of all your specifications separately.)
Is my product a good replica of my drawing?

section.para: If you answer "no" to any of these questions you must make suggestions of how you could improve.
(Fill in your own specifications in the first column.)

para.emphasis: Did I achieve it? Yes / No
